div1.head: Jim to Mlle. Marcelle Guerin April 23rd 1917
div1.p:
I’m very well pleased with our new post. Its a most delightful town where we have our base, and we’re welcomed with open arms. I’m glad we’re in a place where we can do really useful work. I had a job yesterday that took me 44 kilometers into a place forte. We’re under strict military rule here; have to give the pass word and all of the frills. The Germans take a chance at our town now and then. Night before last they turned loose a few obus [?] trying to reach the station. Two little children playing in the street were killed. We went down to see the damage. A large crowd of soldiers gathered around
but no one seemed to be disturbed by the fact that we were in the direct line of a battery that had fired a few minutes before. Late that evening I went to the spot again and picked up part of the shell. Up above I could hear the breast deep sobs of the young mother crying over the poor little mangled bodies of her only children. It was very pitiful. Yesterday morning light shells came in. A woman was killed in her bed about 400 yards from us. The peculiar part about a bombardment to me is that one can hear the firing
of the cannons long before the shell arrives. There is a faint “boom” away off; then a “zipp - zipp, zipp, zipp”, as one tearing parchment, and suddenly an ear - splitting crash. After a few of them one doesn’t mind the racket or pay any attention to the shells. Guns are firing all the time but its the cause of no more excitement than an automobile in Paris.

I’m writing this letter from our advance point where we work in shifts of thirty six hours. We’re in a town that is under practically continuous bombardment
but things are going on all the same. There are good shops, and tho [sic] holes are thru [sic] most of them, business is flourishing. To get here from our base we pass for a kilometer along a road that is under bombardment. Its quite thrilling. One car hits it up across the shell marked area. When the dust has settled the next car turns on full speed and whizzes along the entertaining stretch. We get our wounded about 200 yds from the trenches. The enemy’s trenches are but fourteen hundred yards from our town and they could pot [?] us
with rifles if they wished to.

At our base are some German prisoners and you should see the looks they give us, thinking us English. Their uniform is wonderful. It can hardly be seen, so well does it blend in with all surroundings.

To night I’m sleeping in our advance post and they tell me that we’re to have an unusually fierce bombardment. We have beds here tho [sic] just as at our base. At the latter place one of our men and I share a large bed in the home of two very nice old souls where we are billited [sic]. They are quite friendly towards
me and can’t do too much for us. When I left this morning they expressed all sorts of hopes that I’d get back.

This morning at our advance place a fellow came into see us who looked as if he’d just stepped off Broadway. He wore an American fedora; tan shoes, an English rain coat and his trousers that were turned up were perfectly pressed. I couldn’t understand what the man was doing out here at the front. He explained to us that he had left New York a year and a half ago to do engineering work at a large factory
near us. He was going home for a vacation when the war broke out. Then he decided to stick to his post and so here he is just as American as ever. He was overjoyed to see us, and told us all about the time the Germans were here and many other interesting experiences. He’s coming around to night to see us again.

All the French officers I’ve met are perfect “corkers”. They’re the nicest men I’ve ever met. About half speak English very well. So do about an eighth of the soldiers. Its remarkable.
I’ve all sorts of interesting things to tell you when I see you again that I can’t write about. I hope I shall hear from you soon.
How’s old Rockwell getting along? I’m afraid I can’t get in to his wedding for we’re not allowed to leave here. Even our supply cars have to stop at a point very much in the rear of our place.
